proof:
We begin by fixing an edge $uv \in \varphi_3^+ \subseteq E_H$ such that $u \ne v$. Let us define $\tilde{u} = \arg\max_{w \in \{u,v\}} d(w)$ to be the vertex with the larger degree between $u$ and $v$, and let $\tilde{v}$ be the other vertex. It follows from this definition that $d(\tilde{u}) = M_{uv}$. We can then express $x_{uv}$ as follows:
$$ x_{uv} = 1 - \frac{|N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{d(\tilde{u})} = \frac{d(\tilde{u}) - |N_H(u) \cap N_H(v)|}{d(\tilde{u})} = \frac{|\varphi_1^+(\tilde{u})| + |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{u})| + |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})| - |N_H(\tilde{u}) \cap N_H(\tilde{v})|}{d(\tilde{u})} $$
$$ \le \frac{\text{cost}_C(\tilde{u}) + |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{u})| + |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v})| + \text{cost}_C(\tilde{v})}{d(\tilde{u})} \le \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)| + |\varphi_2^+(v)| + \text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} \quad (5) $$
To justify the first inequality in the sequence (5), we observe that $N_H(\tilde{u}) \supseteq \varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})$. Consequently, we have:
$$ |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})| - |N_H(\tilde{u}) \cap N_H(\tilde{v})| \le |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u})| - |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u}) \cap N_H(\tilde{v})| = |\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v})| \le |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v}) \cup \varphi_1^-(\tilde{v})| $$
$$ = |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v}) \cup \varphi_1^-(\tilde{v})| \le |\varphi_2^+(\tilde{v})| + \text{cost}_C(\tilde{v}). $$
The reasoning above uses the fact that $\varphi_3^+(\tilde{u}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v}) \subseteq C(\tilde{u}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v}) = C(\tilde{v}) \setminus N_H(\tilde{v}) \subseteq \varphi_1^+(\tilde{v}) \cup \varphi_1^-(\tilde{v})$. Furthermore, for any $uv \in \varphi_3^+$, the inequality (5) is trivially true when $u=v$.
Using this result, we can bound $f_3^+$ as follows:
$$ f_3^+ = \sum_{u \in U} y_3^+(u) $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)| + |\varphi_2^+(v)| + \text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(w)}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(v) + \text{cost}_C(w)}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{\text{cost}_C(u) + \text{cost}_C(v)}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ =: \sum_{r \in V} c_3^+(r) \cdot \text{cost}_C(r). $$
Here, the last inequality was derived by applying Lemma 3.3 twice. This establishes that property (3.8a) is satisfied.

To prove (3.8b), we inspect the coefficients associated with $\text{cost}_C(u)$, $\text{cost}_C(v)$, and $\text{cost}_C(w)$ in the final expression. For a vertex $u \in U$, the coefficient of $\text{cost}_C(u)$ is:
$$ \sum_{uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)| \cdot |\varphi_2^+(u)|}{\beta d^2(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} $$
The coefficient corresponding to $\text{cost}_C(v)$ is:
$$ \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v), vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} + \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v)} \frac{1}{M_{uv}} \le \frac{|\varphi_2^+(v)| \cdot |\varphi_3^+(v)|}{\beta d^2(v)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(v)|}{d(v)}. $$
The coefficient for $\text{cost}_C(w)$ is bounded by:
$$ \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_2^+(w), uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{vw \in \varphi_2^+, u \in U \cap \varphi_3^+(v)} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_2^+(w)} \frac{d(u)}{\beta \cdot d(u) M_{uw}} + \sum_{vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{d(v)}{\beta \cdot d(v) M_{vw}} \le \sum_{u \in U \cap \varphi_2^+(w)} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{uw}} + \sum_{vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{1}{\beta \cdot M_{vw}} = \frac{|\varphi_2^+(w)|}{\beta \cdot d(w)} + \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(w)|}{\beta \cdot d(w)}. $$
From these individual bounds, we can conclude that for any $r \in V$, the coefficient $c_3^+(r)$ satisfies $c_3^+(r) \le 2 \left( \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)||\varphi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(r)} + \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)||\varphi_3^+(r)|}{\beta \cdot d(r)} + \frac{|\varphi_2^+(r)| + |\varphi_3^+(r)|}{d(r)} \right)$.

Finally, we bound the $L_1$-norm, $|c_3^+|_1$, as shown below:
$$ |c_3^+|_1 = \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, uw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{2}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{uw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+, vw \in \varphi_2^+} \frac{2}{\beta \cdot M_{uv} M_{vw}} + \sum_{u \in U, uv \in \varphi_3^+} \frac{2}{M_{uv}} $$
$$ \le \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(u)| \cdot |\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u) \cdot d(u)} + \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_2^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{2 \cdot |\varphi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} \right) $$
$$ = 2 \sum_{u \in U} \left( \frac{|\varphi_2^+(u)| \cdot |\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d^2(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)|}{\beta \cdot d(u)} + \frac{|\varphi_3^+(u)|}{d(u)} \right) $$
This completes the proof of (3.8c) and therefore of Lemma 3.8.
